Comment 3: 
2.9 * 24 is not 69.6 in computer math.  It is something like 69.599999999999994.  If you
want a decimal fraction to reliably turn into an integer when multiplied, you must use a
fraction that is an exact power of two, which is why I suggested .9375.

The gc and gccgo behaviour differs because they use very different representations for
floating point constants, but both are permitted by the spec.  Gccgo uses
http://www.mpfr.org with a 256 bit mantissa.
